annotation.TEXT: With that being said, don't expect me to do the same for this one. Future is easily the worst boss in the game. Aside from spawning a never-ending barrage of scythes akin to Death from Castlevania, he generally floats out of your range for most of the fight.

The Ghost of Christmas Present isn't exactly easy, though I think this is mostly attributed to his falling ornament attack. Even on the normal difficulty setting, they can leave very little room for you to avoid getting hit (mostly by Present himself, who will fall directly on you after the last ornament falls).

There are several medals you can get in this game, ranging from Bronze, Silver, Gold, and "Dragon." The last one is obtained by doing a perfect run on any boss without getting hit (all of which can be obtained by doing the "wut" mode difficulty, in which you outright die in a single hit regardless).

Just to note: There's actually a score system in this game, along with an (overly lengthy) totals screen after you beat each boss (which you can't skip). For the sake of convenience, I've edited most of these out. It's not like the score really does anything, aside from going towards a possible online leader-board (which is currently down at the moment, effectively making the scoring system even more pointless).

Jacob Marley is probably the most straight-forward boss fight in the game, though you can still just as easily die to him as the others. The main reason for this is the rather high amount of damage he deals (especially from bumping into him), along with the fact that he more or less constantly swings his chain. You'll need to carefully time your movements against him unless you want to lose roughly 25% or more of your health in a single hit.

For those of you that have watched Christmas specials before, you'll probably recognize the upcoming bosses: Snow Miser and Heat Miser are both auto-scrolling battles, and both generally work the same but with some slightly different attack motions. The only thing I'd say is really difficult about this fight is dodging Snow Miser's three-way ice spread (I still haven't found a consistent way to dodge it yet).

If you're Bass, this isn't much of a problem considering the double jump and buster aiming. If you're Mega Man, you can still hit him with a charged shot...barely, if you time it right. If you're Proto Man however, you have to rely on either using weapons or bouncing his scythes back with your shield for the first part of the battle (should the timer at the top run out, he'll teleport to the ground, making him easier to hit but also causing you to lose out on an achievement).

The first phase of the final boss starts off with the "Twin Duff Cannons." Though they share the same lifebar, they both have their own individual health-points. When you destroy one of them, the cannon is then replaced by another machine that creates a constant wind effect for the rest of the battle (it's also worth noting that the platforms underneath the cannons also go down with them once they're destroyed).

The second phase is a bit more involved, to say the least. You need to be fast to avoid the stream of shots fired from the eye. In-between these streams, the mouth will also spit out enemies (though you can also destroy the mouth quite easily as well).

As you can see here, the intended way to hit the boss is to ride on top of the hand and shoot at him during this brief opportunity. You also can't shoot directly up at him with Bass (as also demonstrated here). Fortunately, you can still cheat your way out of the intended (and rather tedious) process by using Bass' double jump. The same thing can be done with Rush Coil and Carry as well, provided you obtained the code for them.

Mega Man Christmas Carol Remix, as its title would imply, is a remake of its initial flash game counterpart. The remixed version is essentially an upgrade with more mechanics and features, along with generally being the more playable of the two.

At half health, the other eye opens. Instead of shooting a stream of bullets however, this one fires out a homing shot. This is easily the most annoying thing about this fight, if mainly due to how hectic this projectile is. Sometimes it actually does lock onto your position, but most of the time, it just seems to follow whatever type of random pattern it can come up with.

Anyways, it's time for the main event. This game is primarily a boss rush. As hinted at before: Since this game is rather short, and since none of these guys are Ukege-levels of difficulty, it's not exactly worth using weapons on most of them. With that being said, it's buster-only time. The only instance of weapon usage will be for getting extra items.

If you're not using weapons, the best thing to do for this fight is to spread out your attacks between the two cannons. As said before, they both have their own health points. This means you can take down one right after another if you focus on both rather than a single cannon.

If you are using weapons however, the easiest way to beat these two is to summon Venus with the "Past Minion" ability. The constant barrage of Bubble Bombs will pretty much do all the work for you if you position it right.
MYAH! (I personally blame this on the fact that I watched too many of Joel's videos before starting this playthrough).

Aside from looking even more evil than usual today, Bass is probably the easiest character to control, but also has his own hang-ups with certain bosses (especially if you're not using weaknesses). On that note, the code I input at the title screen is one you get for beating the game on hard mode. This unlocks all the weapons from this game and its sequel. However, the only reason I'll be using them is for showing off how to get certain items.

The Ghost of Christmas Past here has a rather obvious gimmick, though still a rather interesting one. Aside from being able to summon various, albeit weaker incarnations of past Robot Masters, the statues at the top of the screen can also come to life and join the fight (with each one having their own individual health-bar as well).
So then, here's a game I somehow haven't gotten around to yet. Given the time of year, I figured this would be a fitting choice for a playthrough.

I have to admit, although I generally enjoy this game, some of the sprite-work (at least, in terms of the opening cutscenes) is a bit...off, shall we say. You'll see what I mean when some of the other characters show up.

Yeah...like I said, it's a bit off. Either way, I'm not exactly doing this to critique the cutscenes. The game itself can actually be quite difficult under the right conditions, regardless of which character you play as (though Proto Man has the toughest time out of all of them, if only due to the fact that he can handle getting hit about as well as Owata can).
